docs.lead_paragraph: THE rest of the United States is starting to look a lot more like Montana. With economic growth recently reaching its fastest quarterly pace since 1984 and companies adding jobs last month, the recovery seems more solid than it has at any other point in the last two years. That could eventually translate into broad increases in income and health insurance coverage and a decline in poverty.
docs.abstract: AFL-CIO analysis finds Montana leading nation in economic growth; map shows economic conditions state by state

docs.lead_paragraph: Can anything besides an act of God stop the rise of college tuition? For the last several months on Capitol Hill, the higher-education establishment has been on the defensive over the question -- and at times things have gotten very testy.
docs.abstract: Christopher Shea article rebuts common beliefs about high costs at state universities; photos; list of in-state tuition at nation's public universities (special section, Education Life) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: August Marziliano is clear about his hopes for his 7-year-old son Antonio, who was born with cerebral palsy and now relies on a wheelchair. ''I would like to see him walk,'' he said. ''That's the biggest thing, if I ever saw him walk ----'' Mr. Marziliano, 44, stopped abruptly, turned to his son and said, ''Antonio, what will Daddy do when I see you walk?''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Father's Dream: Seeing His Son Walk

docs.abstract: Single father on Staten Island gets help from Catholic Charities of Archdiocese of New York, which is supported by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, in paying for after-school program and summer day camp for his 7-year-old son with cerebral palsy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Maggie Mateer was offered a job last July as an accountant for the Xerox Corporation, she hesitated. It wasn't that she did not want the job, or that the salary was too low. Ms. Mateer, who had five years of experience as a certified public accountant, wanted to pore over the details of the company's health plan before she signed on. Only after grilling a Xerox human resources representative for more than half an hour -- and finding out that she would be paying $100 less a month out of pocket for health coverage than she had been -- did Ms. Mateer, 26, accept the job. She is now based at the company's headquarters in Rochester.

headline.main: In Many Recruitment Efforts, Health Benefits Act as Lure

docs.abstract: Increasing number of Americans are closely studying company health benefits before accepting new jobs, striking change from late 1990's, when salary and career potential were key issues; Maggie Mateer explains decision to work for Xerox; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: TOMORROW morning, Dr. Michele Chai will go to work at the neonatal intensive care unit of the Hamot Medical Center in Erie, Pa., where she is a neonatologist. The next three days she will be on call 24 hours a day. While she is working, her husband, Jonathan, will be home, caring for their three children, ages 6, 4 and 2. Then, on Thursday, they will switch. Jonathan will go to work at the same job, in the same intensive care unit of the same hospital. It will be Michele's turn to stay home.

headline.main: Sharing a Life, a Family and a Workweek

docs.abstract: Life's Work column about professional couples who share one well-paying job as solution to work and child care issues; neonatologists Drs Michele and Jonathan Chai, pastors Amy Jacks and Russ Dean and astrophysicists Nicholas McCord Schneider and Erica Ellingson explain schedules; Schneider and Ellingson share tenure-track position at University of Colorado (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidates persisted in pounding President Bush about the economy on Friday, even in the face of new data showing strong growth in jobs last month that the president said was a vindication of his policies. ''Good luck in using statistics to convince working Americans that the Bush administration has their economic interests at heart,'' Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts said in Salem, N.H., in remarks typical of all the potential challengers. ''The deep unfairness of the Bush economy is real to Americans.''

headline.main: Job Figures Buoy Bush, but Democratic Hopefuls See Room to Attack

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidates continue pounding Pres Bush on economy, despite jobs report suggesting recovery may be genuine; Bruce Reed of Democratic Leadership Council and other party advisers believe race still will be run on economy; Bush sees evidence that his polices are working, speech at North Carolina fund-raiser that brings in $1.1 million; photo (M)
